      <title>Botched cosmetic surgery: law change urged as complaints treble</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/botched-cosmetic-surgery-law-change-urged-as-complaints-treble</link>
      <description><p>Celebrity endorsements on social media have led more to seek bargain-price fillers and Botox</p><p>An “alarming” rise in reports of botched cosmetic procedures in the UK has prompted doctors and campaigners to call for better legislation <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2017/jun/22/protect-children-from-online-cosmetic-surgery-apps-say-campaigners">to protect against </a>rogue practitioners.</p><p>The number of problems related to treatments such as lip fillers and Botox has almost trebled, jumping from 378 in 2016 to 931 in the space of 12 months, according to data from Save Face, a government-approved register of accredited practitioners. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/botched-cosmetic-surgery-law-change-urged-as-complaints-treble">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Would you like a daily reminder that death is round the corner?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/would-you-like-a-daily-reminder-that-death-is-round-the-corner-</link>
      <description><p>A new app, We Croak, notifies you five times a day that you could die at any moment. It’s a memento mori on your mobile, but does it make you feel more alive?</p><p>It’s Friday night and after a fraught week I am waiting for pizza. I ordered over an hour ago, but nothing seems to be happening. A notification buzzes on my phone and maddened with dough lust, I snatch it up. “Don’t forget, you’re going to die,” says the message. Suddenly I’m not so hungry any more.</p><p>Welcome to <a href="https://www.wecroak.com/">WeCroak</a>, the app that reminds you of death five times a day. Created by 35-year-old Brooklyn-based publicist Hansa Bergwall and developer Ian Thomas, WeCroak couldn’t be simpler: a randomly timed reminder you swipe to reveal a death-related quotation, sometimes gloomy, sometimes uplifting. Based on a Bhutanese proverb that to be happy, you must contemplate death five times a day, it’s mindfulness noir.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/would-you-like-a-daily-reminder-that-death-is-round-the-corner-">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>A quick note to say thank you… to the tractor driver who dialled 999</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/cyclist-says-thank-you-to-the-tractor-driver-who-dialled-999</link>
      <description><p>A cyclist who suffered a terrible crash and a spine broken in two places, pays tribute to the simple act of a kindness of a passing driver</p><p>I was cycling alone on a country lane near Norwich when I went over the handlebars and landed on the top of my head. If I hadn’t been wearing a helmet, I’d have certainly died, since the ground was hard and it was like crashing on to concrete. I felt my neck concertina and my first thought was that I’d broken it. In fact, I’d broken my back in two places.</p><p>There was a tractor coming and the driver stopped. The first thing he did was dial 999, then he helped me up on to my feet. With hindsight that probably wasn’t ideal, and I remember finding it hard to breathe, but I stood there holding on to my bike and he directed the traffic round us and we waited for the ambulance. I knew it was bad, and I guess standing up made me think it wasn’t as bad as it might have been, but it was all incredibly scary.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/cyclist-says-thank-you-to-the-tractor-driver-who-dialled-999">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Lord of the ring: from the gym to a new self-confidence</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/lord-of-the-ring-from-gym-to-new-self-confidence-nikesh-shukla</link>
      <description><p>After weeks of hard training down at the boxing gym, Nikesh has learned the most crucial lesson of all…</p><p>They decide to start opening the gym at 7.30am instead of 10am, which is perfect for me. I go three mornings a week. It’s just me, the owner and one of the coaches who spends his idle moments mopping the floors and cleaning. The first morning I go, the owner is surprised to see me. He asks why I’m so early. I tell him it fits into my life easier than other times. He tells me I’m the only person so far to take up the new early opening, but knowing I’m here makes it worth it. He asks how I’m getting on. I tell him I’m gaining confidence. I find the classes good, but I like the quiet. I can focus.</p><p>I skip one round by myself and put the rope down, ready to move on. The coach who is mopping the floor asks if I’m done skipping. I nod my head. I hate skipping. I can, at best, manage, 20 seconds without whipping the rope across the backs of my bare legs, or tripping. I find it frustrating. It. Looks. So. Easy. Why. Is. It. So. Hard?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/lord-of-the-ring-from-gym-to-new-self-confidence-nikesh-shukla">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Will Self: ‘I’m fitter than I’ve ever been’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/will-self-im-fitter-than-ive-ever-been-walking</link>
      <description><p>The novelist, 56, on the health benefits of eating less and walking more</p><p>When I was a child and my parents separated, I went on walking holidays with my dad. My rubric’s always been to walk from home – I’m not a rambler. It’s about a sense of being and place and engagement with the environment around me.</p><p>I like wild swimming, particularly in the sea – I swim out, then float and look at the horizon. I think that’s extremely good for the imagination. I still cycle even though I was knocked off my bike a few years ago, but mostly in the summer – it’s too dangerous in the winter in London.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/will-self-im-fitter-than-ive-ever-been-walking">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>My husband died and my son is angry I’m in a new relationship | Dear Mariella</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/my-husband-died-and-my-son-is-angry-i-am-in-a-new-relationship-mariella-frostrup</link>
      <description><p>Mothers and sons is the greatest love story never told, says Mariella Frostrup. Stay patient but don’t stop seeing your new lover</p><p><strong><em>The dilemma</em></strong><em> My husband died suddenly early last year. It has been tough for me and for my teen/20s children. We’ve worked hard to support our grief and have been close. They have lovely friends and special loves who have been wonderful and supportive – and they are OK, me too.</em></p><p><em>I have become close to someone I have known vaguely for 10 years. He is lovely and we seem to have embarked on something special. In our 50s neither of us want to fanny about and he seems willing to accept the baggage I carry (and he has some, too).&nbsp;I feel the same. </em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/my-husband-died-and-my-son-is-angry-i-am-in-a-new-relationship-mariella-frostrup">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Let a rail journey speed by with the wave of a mascara wand</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/let-a-rail-journey-speed-by-with-the-wave-of-a-mascara-wand</link>
      <description><p>What better place to try out new make-up?</p><p>I do my make-up on the train. Be it schlepping between Margate and London, gallivanting to music festivals, heading to Birmingham to see one of my oldest friends or going up to the Fringe to give Edinburgh a kiss.</p><p>I do enjoy my pinball life, although sometimes my head feels as heavy as lead as it drops to sleep on yet another train, and moments of audiobook bliss can sometimes be interrupted with flickers of anxiety for being so transient. I don’t travel particularly light, either, utilising every bit of my body you can hang jewellery from.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/let-a-rail-journey-speed-by-with-the-wave-of-a-mascara-wand">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Designer label Preen launches collection starting at just 65p</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/18/designer-label-preen-launches-postage-stamp-collection-starting-65p-duchess-cambrige-finella-dress</link>
      <description><p>Catwalk label’s postage stamp collection features Finella dress worn by Duchess of Cambridge</p><p>Preen, the catwalk label designed by the husband and wife team Justin Thornton and Thea Bregazzi and worn by the Duchess of Cambridge and Gwyneth Paltrow, has launched London fashion week’s most affordable collection, with prices starting at just 65p.</p><p>However, the bargain buys are the size of a postage stamp – literally. A six-stamp collection celebrating 20 years of the brand has been issued by the Isle of Man, where both Thornton and Bregazzi grew up. The first-class stamp features the red Finella dress <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/sep/30/the-duchess-of-cambridge-ambassador-of-british-style-post-brexit">worn by the duchess on a royal tour of Canada</a>. The bodycon “Power Dress” that first made the label famous is honoured on another of the stamps.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/18/designer-label-preen-launches-postage-stamp-collection-starting-65p-duchess-cambrige-finella-dress">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The big picture: London Fashion Week, February 1998</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/18/big-picture-british-fashion-week-martin-parr</link>
      <description>With the 2018 event now in full swing, we revisit a telling Martin Parr shot from 20 years ago<p>Martin Parr is the kind of quick-witted photographer who catches life on the run, his shutter clicking faster than the human eye can blink. To coincide with London Fashion Week, which began last Friday, here is a deft act of espionage from backstage at the same event 20 years ago. Parr probably didn’t know what he’d snatched until he developed the film and saw that the flustered accidents of a moment had come to rest in a parable, showing how the beauty industry goes about its tortuous, tormenting work.</p><p>Makeup has already transformed the model into a doll: the waxen complexion, with a sickly jaundiced tone around the eyes, and the pursed, painted lips that are smaller and more infantile than her own. Now the hairdressers take over, knotting and coiling and pinning and teasing, with a can of eco-unfriendly aerosol spray ready to freeze her mane. They are technicians, busy on the assembly line; she is their manufactured product, as glassy-eyed as the lens of Parr’s camera.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/18/big-picture-british-fashion-week-martin-parr">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/london-fashion-week">London fashion week</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/photography">Photography</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/martin-parr">Martin Parr</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>

    <item>
      <title>Michael Halpern dazzles London Fashion Week with platforms and sequins</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/18/michael-halpern-designer-london-fashion-week-platforms-sequins</link>
      <description><p>The spotlight falls on the designer with a vision is to provide a moment of escapism in dark times</p><p>The question of where fashion sits within the ongoing post-Weinstein cultural awakening feels more pertinent than ever this weekend. Patrick Demarchelier, Princess Diana’s personal fashion photographer, <a href="https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2018/02/16/beauty-and-ugly-truth/c7r0WVsF5cib1pLWXJe9dP/story.html" title="">has denied sexual misconduct accusations</a>. A proposed all-black dress code in support of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jan/01/times-up-hollywood-women-launch-campaign-to-fight-sexual-harassment" title="">Time’s Up, the campaign against sexual harassment,</a> will dominate the red carpet at the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/jan/09/full-list-of-nominations-for-the-baftas-2018-film" title=""> Bafta awards</a>, an international event that falls in the middle of this week’s London shows.</p><p>For the New York designer Michael Halpern, 30, the timing is perfect. His London-based label Halpern, a cavalcade of sequins and colour, is currently one of the most popular in womenswear. “This idea of inappropriate glamour, or of questioning what is too much in fashion, or goes too far…” Halpern told the <em>Observer</em>, “What’s going on in with women and politics has pushed me to want to make a statement with what I design.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/18/michael-halpern-designer-london-fashion-week-platforms-sequins">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Christopher Bailey bows out from Burberry under a bold rainbow</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/18/christopher-bailey-bows-out-from-burberry-under-a-bold-rainbow</link>
      <description>An adventurous last show from the form-breaking British designer who reinvented Burberry<p>For 17 years at Burberry, Christopher Bailey has rejoiced in rain. It is, after all, both quintessential British weather and the perfect setting for a trenchcoat. But for his <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2017/oct/31/christopher-bailey-burberry-transformed-fashion-brand" title="">last catwalk show</a> for London Fashion Week’s biggest brand, the sun came out and Bailey’s reign ended beneath a rainbow.</p><p>The show opened with Adwoa Aboah in rainbow stripes on a white silk skirt and closed with Cara Delevingne under a rainbow fake fur coat. Puffa jackets and hi-top trainers came with rainbow stripes, and a trenchcoat and a blanket cape in a technicolour version of the distinctive beige check. This season the Burberry check is rainbow-hued, a symbol of the firm’s financial support for LGBTQ+ charities.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/18/christopher-bailey-bows-out-from-burberry-under-a-bold-rainbow">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The beauty bargains that beat the luxury brands | Sali Hughes</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/17/beauty-bargains-that-beat-the-luxury-brands</link>
      <description><p>From micellar water to liquid eyeliner, these top-quality products are a fraction of the price of luxury brands</p><p>I try almost every new micellar cleansing water that comes on to the market, simply because I get through gallons of the stuff. I use it as an eye makeup remover; for sweeping away the hundreds of stripes and smears of testing makeup drawn on my hands each week; for removing the bulk of makeup before proper night-time face cleansing with a balm; for overtired, tipsy cleansing from the comfort of my own bed; and for swift, neat lipstick changes on shoots.</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2013/apr/27/sali-hughes-liquid-cleansers">I&nbsp;have tried hundreds</a>, from dirt cheap to silly expensive, and <a href="http://www.boots.com/simple-water-boost-micellar-cleansing-water-400ml-10233099"><strong>Simple’s Water Boost micellar cleansing water</strong></a> (£6.99 for a huge 400ml bottle) is the best at any price. Here is why: unlike many micellars, it doesn’t give me spots. If ever I&nbsp;am testing anti‑blemish treatments on my dry, normally clear face and I use an inferior micellar for a few days, a spot or two will materialise. Not with this – however frequently I&nbsp;use it. It&nbsp;removes everything, even stubborn matte lip stains, with ease. It leaves my skin neither greasy nor tight. It is cheap enough to be used lavishly and has a proper squirty bottle instead of the stupid, wasteful and messy pump dispensers favoured by several luxury brands. At this stage, I&nbsp;see no reason why anyone would pay more.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/17/beauty-bargains-that-beat-the-luxury-brands">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Anti-fur protests set to fly as activists target London fashion week</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/16/london-fashion-week-fur-set-fly-animal-rights-activists-protests</link>
      <description><p>Animal rights campaigners plan largest demonstrations in decade as designers move away from fur</p><p><br>Boosted by the vogue for veganism, animal rights activists plan to target London fashion week this weekend with the largest fur protests seen at the event in a decade. Ed Winters, the co-director of Surge, which orchestrated anti-fur demonstrations that attractedmore than 250 people in September, a rise from 120 the previous catwalk season and 25 in September 2016, said “we expect those numbers to continually rise” .</p><p>There is, however, unlikely to be much fur on the catwalks. Over 90% of designers taking part in LFW have confirmed to the British Fashion Council (BFC) that they will not be using fur. But research by the University of Copenhagen reports retail sales of fur in the UK in 2016 were £162m, up 350% from 2011, as inexpensive real fur has become commonplace in fast fashion.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/16/london-fashion-week-fur-set-fly-animal-rights-activists-protests">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>What I wore this week: a turtle neck</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/16/what-i-wore-this-week-a-turtle-neck</link>
      <description><p>The polo neck can’t stay in fashion for ever, so prepare for the inevitable with this sleeker, sportier alternative</p><p>What did we wear before polo necks were a thing? It gives me neck chills just thinking about it. A cravat? Seems unlikely, but I cannot honestly remember. I have worn a polo neck, either by itself or as a base layer under a shirt or dress, pretty much every other day this winter and last and the one before that. A polo neck is cosy without being bulky, modern without being mannered. It just works.</p><p>At some point, the polo neck will be over and I need to prepare myself for this eventuality. It will fade from favour, slip down the ratings from on-point to passable until we reach the day when bumping into someone you know while wearing one is borderline awks. <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/30/ugg-the-look-that-refused-to-die">Like getting spotted in Uggs</a>. (A dog comes in handy here. Seriously, you can get away with wearing any old tat if you are walking a dog. A year and a half into dog ownership, I can report confidently that even if you look like you styled your outfit while escaping a burning building, no one will judge you if you have got a cockapoo with you. I don’t know why this is. It is not like a dog gets to spring a walk on you. Anyway.)</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/16/what-i-wore-this-week-a-turtle-neck">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Explore it with a local: Leeuwarden, the Netherlands’ capital of culture</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/18/leeuwarden-the-netherlands-european-capital-of-culture-with-a-local</link>
      <description><p>The best way to see this year’s joint European Capital of Culture is to ask the residents to show you their city – for free</p><p>It’s just after 10am and I’m cycling through the narrow cobblestone streets of Leeuwarden in the Netherlands, past canals with ivy-covered banks and perfectly preserved 17th-century merchant houses, thanks to Mila and her boyfriend Wilmar, our guides for the day. “Bike is by far the best way to see the city,” says Mila. “The only rule is you’ve got to bring us back afterwards. And in the same condition.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/18/leeuwarden-the-netherlands-european-capital-of-culture-with-a-local">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/18/leeuwarden-the-netherlands-european-capital-of-culture-with-a-local</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/bf89a6d40bb345913348eeadd0a96382618cd8b6/0_414_6480_3888/master/6480.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=bdbaae52c500c33cfa1783a28d030768">

    <item>
      <title>How to book and travel by high-speed train around China</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/16/how-to-book-travel-high-speed-train-china-shanghai-beijing-shenzhen</link>
      <description><p>China’s rail network is a fast-paced wonder that makes exploring this huge country – including Beijing, Shanghai and Shenzhen – much easier<br>• <strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/16/china-by-train-tracks-tales-chinese-new-year">China by train: tracks, tales and a snapshot of daily life</a></strong></p><p>Friday is Chinese new year and also the beginning of the spring festival, a national holiday in China (known as Chun Jie), which heralds what has been called the largest human migration in the world, with millions of people making journeys home for the holidays. China’s growing high-speed rail network – which is the longest in the world, too – carries a significant transport burden, with almost 60% of the population using it over a three-week-plus period.</p><p>It’s not just locals who can take advantage of the vastly improved journey times that the network offers: tourists too can use high-speed trains to visit more of China – and a whole lot faster. Many high-speed rail journeys are, ultimately, quicker than flying.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/16/how-to-book-travel-high-speed-train-china-shanghai-beijing-shenzhen">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>China by train: tracks, tales and a snapshot of everyday life</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/16/china-by-train-tracks-tales-chinese-new-year</link>
      <description><p>Chinese new year signals major travel across the country, and railways are at the heart of many journeys. Author and BBC journalist Michael Bristow knows China well – and the insight time on board offers</p><ul><li><strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/16/how-to-book-travel-high-speed-train-china-shanghai-beijing-shenzhen">How to travel by high-speed train around China</a></strong></li></ul><p>Chinese people will make nearly 400 million train trips over Chinese new year (16 February this year). Migrant workers will leave the cities and head back to the countryside to see their children; students will travel home for the long winter holiday; elderly parents will visit their grown-up children.</p><p>The mass arrival of cars and planes has changed the nature of travel in China but the railways remain the country’s most important form of transport. However, trains do not just get you from A to B: in China, these often long journeys give travellers a snapshot of ordinary life, a sense of where they are.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/16/china-by-train-tracks-tales-chinese-new-year">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/17/blondies-brownie-recipe-sour-cherry-bay-leaf-cream-ruby-tandoh</link>
      <description><p>Beautify your brownies with these grown-up blondies spiced up with citrus and cherries</p><p>Usually I like to take a recipe straight to its basest form: opera cake? Make that a chocolate sponge. Towering <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Croquembouche">croquembouche</a>? Serve ‘em a nice eclair instead. These blondies are unusual for me, then, because for once I’ve taken something a bit saccharine and naff and made it classier. Brought to life with citrussy cardamom and plump cherries, these avoid the cloying sweetness of traditional blondies, while the bay-infused cream adds a subtle aniseed warmth. They might only be brownies with a wig on, but they taste a million bucks.</p><p>Prep <strong>20 mins</strong><br>Cook <strong>30-35 mins</strong> <br>Serves 12 </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/17/blondies-brownie-recipe-sour-cherry-bay-leaf-cream-ruby-tandoh">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>A seasonal cake shot through with a moreish ruby syrup, heavy with sharply sweet citrus flavour</p><p>Little did I know when I wrote this recipe that polenta and citrus cakes are all the rage in coffee shops around the country. Well, the heart wants what the heart wants, and seemingly many hearts want this. It’s not hard to see why: polenta, or ground corn, makes for a deliciously dense cake, which is here topped and shot through with a sharp, brightly flavoured, ruby-coloured syrup made with blood orange. Those oranges aren’t around for long, so don’t dilly-dally.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/17/vegan-blood-orange-polenta-cake-recipe-meera-sodha">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Temple Cycles Adventure review: ‘Perfect for hill passes, pints and pasties’ | Martin Love</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/18/temple-cycles-adventure-disc-trail-bristol-bespoke-review-martin-love</link>
      <description><p>Whatever two-wheel adventures you are planning, this classy take on the all-round gravel bike will make the ideal companion</p><p><strong>Temple Cycles Adventure Disc<br></strong><strong>Price</strong> £1,595, <a href="https://www.templecycles.co.uk/">templecycles.co.uk</a><br><strong>Frame</strong> Reynolds steel<br><strong>Gears</strong> Shimano 105<br><strong>Saddle</strong> Brooks<br><strong>Brakes</strong> TRP Spyre</p><p>If you’ve cycled in the West Country, you’ll know it’s all about hills, hills, more hills and then, always, a flagstoned pub with a pint waiting for you at the end of a long day’s ride. It’s pain followed by pleasure. Chuck in a cheese and onion pasty and you’ve got the full “proper job”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/18/temple-cycles-adventure-disc-trail-bristol-bespoke-review-martin-love">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Is a 1-litre engine enough? The new compact crossover from Seat proves you can pack a punch no matter your size</p><p><strong>Seat Arona<br></strong><strong>Price </strong>£15,555<br><strong>Top speed</strong> 113mph<br><strong>0-62mph</strong> 11.2 seconds<br><strong>MPG</strong> 57.6<br><strong>CO<sub>2</sub></strong> 111g/km</p><p>For a certain generation of people, the idea of a 1-litre engine is total anathema. For them, the very thought of a power unit with less than 1,000cc is laughable – like asking a weedy toddler with a terminal case of nappy rash to ‘tow the truck’ – it’s just not going to get you anywhere. But the <a href="http://www.seat.com/carworlds/arona/overview.html">Arona</a>, the award-winning new city crossover from Seat, not only features a diminutive 1-litre engine, it’s also the size that the Spanish manufacturer recommends. Not only that, brace yourselves, the tiny little engine has also only got three cylinders, an uneven number which old-timers would consider with deep suspicion.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/18/seat-arona-preview-a-savvy-little-car-martin-love">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>A black pudding saved my life</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/16/black-pudding-saved-my-life-mccabe-butcher-totnes-experience</link>
      <description><p>I walked into the freezer in my butcher’s shop – and heard the door slam shut behind me</p><p>I have been running <a href="http://www.mccabesbutchers.co.uk/">a butcher’s shop in Totnes, Devon</a>, for the past 30 years. One blustery day last December, I went to the walk-in freezer to fetch some lamb shanks. I&nbsp;hadn’t stepped in more than a couple of feet when I heard the steel door slam shut behind&nbsp;me. The wind was stronger than I thought, and I hadn’t propped the door open. I&nbsp;had just dashed in and – bang! – it blew shut. Then I realised the emergency release button had frozen. I was trapped.</p><p>Inside the freezer is a huge fan, the guts of the machine, blowing out cold air at -20C. I&nbsp;realised immediately that I had to escape or I’d be dead within the hour. The freezer&nbsp;box&nbsp;is&nbsp;50 yards from the back of the butcher’s shop, so there was no point in banging on the&nbsp;door or&nbsp;shouting for help: no one would have heard me. I had to get myself&nbsp;out.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/16/black-pudding-saved-my-life-mccabe-butcher-totnes-experience">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Is your partner micro-cheating? Let’s face it, whose isn’t…</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/16/is-your-partner-micro-cheating-whose-isnt</link>
      <description><p>So your partner shows a fleeting interest in other men or women? Congratulations… you’ve probably picked well</p><p>Are you guilty of <a href="http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-5257227/Psychologist-explains-micro-cheating-rise.html">“micro-cheating”</a>? I’d forgive you for having no clue, because I’ve now read about two dozen articles on this latest pop-psychology buzzphrase, which <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com.au/2017/08/15/micro-cheating-what-is-it-and-does-it-count_a_23077600/">went viral</a> last month, and I’m more confused than when I started. It refers, as far as I can tell, to seemingly innocuous behaviours that actually count as infidelity. But the examples given by dating experts range from wishing someone happy birthday on Facebook, which plainly isn’t a problem, to taking off your wedding ring before chatting someone up in a bar, which plainly is. (Does your partner <a href="https://www.bustle.com/p/7-signs-someone-is-micro-cheating-on-you-according-to-experts-7932780">talk about their ex</a> too much? That’s micro-cheating. But what’s “too much”? No one will say.) Confusing matters further, micro-cheating apparently also includes things that are obviously signs that your partner is having an affair of the conventional variety. If he spends ages staring goggle-eyed at pictures of another woman on his phone, while you look grumpy on the other side of the bed, there are only two possibilities: either you’re posing for <a href="https://www.gettyimages.com/photos/infidelity">stock photos</a> for magazine articles on relationship problems, or you’ve got a relationship problem.</p><p>Micro-cheating is an unhelpful idea, as the psychologist <a href="https://www.thecut.com/2018/01/micro-cheating-what-it-is-and-why-its-an-unhelpful-concept.html">Justin Lehmiller noted on The Cut website</a>, because it implies that feeling the tiniest attraction to anyone else is a red flag – a notion so at odds with normal human functioning that it sets a standard no relationship could ever meet. Beyond that, like the idea of the “emotional affair” before it, it seems destined to worry or reassure precisely the wrong people. If you’re needy and insecure, you’ll suspect your partner is micro-cheating when they aren’t – possibly even driving them away, creating the very breach you feared. Conversely, if you’re trying to avoid confronting the truth that your relationship is in trouble, you’ll take false comfort if your partner’s actions happen not to tick any boxes on the micro-cheating list.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/16/is-your-partner-micro-cheating-whose-isnt">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Her voice swings between self-consciously raspy and whisper-soft, with a hint of something not quite of this realm</p><p>I’ve just realised that I’ve already bought more music this year than I did in all of 2016. It’s not that I have suddenly developed an appreciation of previously unexplored genres (on the contrary, I have become even more entrenched in loving what I already do) but there has been a lot of excellent music in 2017.</p><p>And as we ease into the second half of the year, there’s no one I’m listening to as much as American singer-songwriter <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/jun/11/sza-ctrl-review">SZA</a>. I am playing her morning, noon and night; in the shower, all day at work, even as I brush my teeth.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2017/jul/01/why-i-love-sza-bim-adewunmi">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Eco-chic and trouser suits: how Meghan Markle’s style reads the room</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/02/eco-chic-and-trouser-suits-how-meghan-markles-style-reads-the-room</link>
      <description><p><strong>The future royal wore a trouser suit for her first official evening engagement with Prince Harry, ushering in a new kind of sartorial diplomacy</strong></p><p>Last night, for her first official evening engagement with Prince Harry, Meghan Markle wore an Alexander McQueen trouser suit. It was slim-fitting, with cropped cigarette trousers, worn with very high stiletto heels and a cream dishabille blouse. The outfit was many things: very <a href="http://www.businessinsider.com/ysls-greatest-fashion-hits-2011-8?op=1&amp;IR=T">Saint Laurent’s Le Smoking</a>, a bit <a href="https://i.pinimg.com/736x/e7/0a/47/e70a4722f480555239d1f18d81fec4fa--casual-elegant-style-casual-elegance.jpg">Princess Diana</a>, with a soupçon of Marlene Dietrich, even a hint of Carine Roitfeld (<a href="http://www.elleuk.com/fashion/news/a22996/carine-roitfeld-dressing-french-parisian-style/">although Roitfeld probably wouldn’t have worn a blouse underneath the tux</a>). What it was not was a Sandringham-appropriate boxy Catherine Walker skirt suit. It was notable because it didn’t feel like standard royal family dressing at all. </p><p>The royal family wrote the rule book on sartorial diplomacy. Usually, their approach is unambiguous. It is <a href="http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/hats-off-maam-the-queen-in-ireland-the-inside-story-of-a-diplomatic-coup-2287454.html">a gown embroidered with 2,091 shamrocks in Ireland</a>; a <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/20/fashion/the-duchess-of-cambridge-wears-chanel-on-brexit-tinged-trip-to-paris.html">Chanel tweed coat in Paris in the middle of Brexit</a>; <a href="https://fashion.hellomagazine.com/fashion-news/201707207005/kate-middleton-style-diplomatic-dressing-royal-tour/">a dress by Polish designer Gosia Baczyńska at a garden party in Warsaw</a>. It is the opposite of wearing a cult band T-shirt that only fellow devotees will recognise. The clothes are designed to speak of decency and propriety; the visual messages are clear enough to charm heads of state and reach the rest of us in the cheap seats as well.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/02/eco-chic-and-trouser-suits-how-meghan-markles-style-reads-the-room">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>A letter to… the ‘rude’ woman who saved my daughter’s life</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/17/a-letter-to-the-rude-woman-who-saved-my-daughters-life</link>
      <description><p>‘Thank you for beeping your horn when you did, for seeing what I hadn’t seen’: the letter you always wanted to write</p><p>It was about seven years ago. I had just picked up my three-year-old daughter from nursery. I was weighed down with shopping, and with my daughter’s things. She scooted alongside me. We arrived at a pedestrian crossing and she pressed the button. In the distance, I heard sirens, told my daughter to wait and watched the police car approach.</p><p>Little did I know, as the green man flashed, that my daughter had begun to scoot into the road. I watched the police car speed towards us – that’s when you beeped your horn and waved frantically to me. My daughter was about a metre from the path of the police car, hidden from their view by your car.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/17/a-letter-to-the-rude-woman-who-saved-my-daughters-life">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>The hit of fresh air in your nostrils? The beauty of the countryside? Hiking is amazing</p><p><strong>What is it?</strong> Just a nice long walk.</p><p><strong>How much does it cost?</strong> Probably an initial outlay of about £50 for some decent gear, and then free for ever.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/jun/04/is-it-worth-hiking-exercise-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/feea05bce468f9ebfbce1ce5cc72e59a78b652a8/0_396_2592_1555/2592.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=40b136ca3fa3d97d9446c671712b5c7d">

    <item>
      <title>After my wife’s death, I want to start dating again</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/16/after-wifes-death-want-start-dating-children</link>
      <description><p>I am still only 27 and feel ready to meet a new partner, but I don’t know how to tell our two small children, let alone raise the subject with any woman I might be interested in</p><p>About 18 months ago, and after four years of happy marriage, my wife suddenly died. I am still only 27 and believe I am ready to start dating again. But I have no idea what to do with things still connected to my wife. Would it be disrespectful to stop wearing my wedding ring? Is it normal to keep the photos of us on display around the house? We have two children and I will never let them forget her, but how do I tell them that I am dating someone new? I haven’t got round to mentioning my situation to any women I may like to go out with in the future. When is a good time to talk about it?</p><p><em>• When leaving a message on this page, please be sensitive to the fact that you are responding to a real person in the grip of a real-life dilemma, who wrote to Private Lives asking for help, and may well view your comments here. Please consider especially how your words or the tone of your message could be perceived by someone in this situation, and be aware that comments that appear to be disruptive or disrespectful to the individual concerned will be removed.</em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/16/after-wifes-death-want-start-dating-children">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Everything you’ve ever wanted to know about eczema (but were too busy scratching to ask)</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/jan/08/everything-about-winter-eczema-too-busy-scratching</link>
      <description><p>Eczema can be a year-round torment for the 1.6 million adults affected in the UK, but winter causes particular misery. So how can you avoid it – or treat it if you have it?</p><p>Winter can be grim: coughs, cold, flu and the general sense of malaise brought on by dark nights, too much food and not enough exercise. And to add to the misery, as the temperature plunges and the heating goes on, normally reliable and trouble-free skin can start to itch, flake and drive a person to distraction. Welcome to the onset of winter eczema. About 1.6 million adults in the UK live with eczema, many since childhood. It can be a year-round torment or flare up in the cold months. A recent <a href="https://www.allergyuk.org/about/latest-news/520-getting-under-the-skin-of-severe-eczema">Allergy UK survey</a> of adults with eczema found that 88% say it has an impact on their daily lives, 58% say it affects personal relationships and 73% claim that their social life suffers. But despite the scale of the problem, adult eczema remains an underfunded, under-recognised and undertreated condition that can cause profound distress.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/jan/08/everything-about-winter-eczema-too-busy-scratching">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Griff Rhys Jones: ‘My best kiss? I kissed all the Spice Girls once’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2017/dec/30/griff-rhys-jones-british-middle-class-apologise-everybody</link>
      <description><p>The actor and comedian on being lazy, losing his cool and public shaming</p><p>Born in Cardiff, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/griff-rhys-jones">Griff Rhys Jones</a>, 64, began his career on the BBC’s <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/1999/jul/12/broadcasting.mondaymediasection">Not The Nine O’Clock News</a>, which ran from 1979-82. He went on to develop a comedy partnership with <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/mel-smith">Mel Smith</a> that lasted 20 years. He is also an Olivier award-winning stage actor. His UK tour, Where Was I?, starts on 18 January. He is married with two children and lives in Suffolk.</p><p><strong>When were you happiest?<br></strong>I’ll be at my happiest today, and probably my gloomiest at some point today, too.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2017/dec/30/griff-rhys-jones-british-middle-class-apologise-everybody">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2017/dec/16/ethan-hawke-actor-most-life-lessons-optimism-marriage-romance</link>
      <description><p>The actor, 47, on being an optimist, avoiding marriage advice and why other people make him anxious</p><p><strong>I have so many bad habits </strong>it’s impossible to measure the worst. My son would say I don’t take enough care with how I dress, my daughter might say I work too much, and my wife that I can’t seem to help in the kitchen at all. But in my opinion I have none.</p><p><strong>As a former kid actor, </strong>I know how hard it is to turn that attention into anything but self-destruction. The heat of the spotlight makes ordinary temperatures real cold.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2017/dec/16/ethan-hawke-actor-most-life-lessons-optimism-marriage-romance">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Samantha Fox on fame at 16, stalkers and David Cassidy: ‘I kneed him and told him where to go’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2017/dec/12/samantha-fox-glamour-model-fame-16-stalkers-david-cassidy</link>
      <description><p>One of the most photographed British women of the 1980s talks about feminism, her abusive father and how she battled her fears to come out as gay<br></p><p>In a small, unloved hotel, the receptionist greets me and Samantha Fox with pursed lips: “There will be no interview here,” she says. I feel as if I’ve wandered into the pages of Fox’s new autobiography, Forever, which is littered with bizarre anecdotes of best-laid plans going awry. From her ill-fated <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/feb/16/sam-fox-brit-awards">presenting partnership</a> with a spaced-out Mick Fleetwood at the 1989 Brit awards, to a secret naked horseback photo shoot in Antigua – during which her steed galloped off with her to a busy tourist beach – not much has gone as expected in Fox’s life. Not least the day she worked with her childhood idol David Cassidy, who died earlier this month, which she says culminated in being <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/dec/11/samantha-fox-accuses-david-cassidy-of-sexual-assault">sexually assaulted</a> by him. Despite these, and many other setbacks, she says she is a “lucky girl”.</p><p>Fox was just 16 when her mother entered her for the Sunday People’s Face and Shape of 1983 competition – her wholesome, girl-next-door image made her the most popular Page 3 girl ever, and one of the most photographed women of the 1980s, alongside Princess Diana and Margaret Thatcher. By 21, she had made her first pop record and retired from modelling, going on to break the US and sell 30m records worldwide.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2017/dec/12/samantha-fox-glamour-model-fame-16-stalkers-david-cassidy">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The view from the front row: a history of the fashion show – photo essay</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/15/the-view-from-the-front-row-a-history-of-the-fashion-show-photo-essay</link>
      <description><p>Once, photographers were banned from fashion shows, with designers suspecting they were spies. Today, fashion shows are a multimillion-dollar global business. As London fashion week begins, we cart the evolution of the fashion show, from secret salons to the snap-happy Instagram era</p><p>Most fashion shows last less than 10 minutes, but have the power to transport an audience to another world. There’s an intensity to a great show, a distillation of a designer’s extraordinary vision. </p><p>Once upon a time, though, things were a lot humbler. The intimate salon shows of Chanel in the 1950s bear no resemblance to Karl Lagerfeld’s fully-stocked supermarket in the vast Grand Palais in 2014. The main change is scale – along with location, set production, and budget. From John Galliano’s historical dramas at Christian Dior, to Hussein Chalayan’s theatrical impossibilities and the late Alexander McQueen’s gothic, heart-stopping wonders, we chart how the fashion show developed from low-key to king.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/15/the-view-from-the-front-row-a-history-of-the-fashion-show-photo-essay">Continue reading...</a></description>
